instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
In for no backlight, 

[ATTACH]60952[/ATTACH]

I cleaned this up and replaced,

<RESISTOR>R7755</RESISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7710</CAPACITOR>
<RESISTOR>R7741</RESISTOR>

Left out <CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR>  as top pad was missing.

I have 3.42 at <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>

tried Pram reset 3/4 times

Did a gentle reflow on <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>

Other side of board  I get 8.55v at F7700 but on xw7720 I get 0v. 
Does this look like a bad <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>?

Problem I have is a guy is driving a long way past me tomorrow to collect this and I dont have any <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> chips left,.
Is there any way to bypass it and get a backlight working?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Be sure all the resistors in the area (opposite board side too) are good.
You can't boost the voltage without <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.

Post <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM levels.
Also check <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>/7 voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>LCDBKCT_EN_L</SIGNAL> =3.70v ( Seems to move up and down a bit to 4.5 then back to 3.7
PWM =0v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>
1- .270v ( Seems to slowley drop )
2- 17.0mV
3 - 6.08v
4- 8.55v
5 - 1.940v
6 - 1.508v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
1- 0v
2 - 3.33v
3- 3.10v
4- 0
5 - 0
6 - 0

All resistors measure good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Sorry about signal names.
I meant <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM.

"<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
5 - 0"
Since <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is missing, backlight circuitry is not enabled yet.
Do you get image on internal LCD for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
100% get image can even shine scope through back of lid and log in.
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> = .233v
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> = 00.3mV

This can't be related to me leaving out  <CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR>  can it? cant see how!

just tried this logic in another known good  machine same result all good can log in just no backlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR> is not critical, forget it.

The big ptoblem there is missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>.
This can be caused by bad <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, which can block communication with PCH through I2C bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Ill order some <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> chips now and replace , thanks dude

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Chips arrived today! Replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and Boom! backlight returns!   

Another one fixed. thanks dude,
